node_2: multi-genre, cross over comic book series
edge: The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen is a multi-genre, cross over comic book series co-created by writer Alan Moore and artist Kevin O'Neill which began in 1999.
Alan Moore is a writer who collaborated with artist Kevin O'Neill to co-create the League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, a multi-genre, cross over comic book series which began in 1999.
Kevin O'Neill is an artist who collaborated with writer Alan Moore to co-create the League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, a multi-genre, cross over comic book series which began in 1999.
The America's Best Comics imprint of DC Comics published the first two volumes and the graphic novel Black Dossier of The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series.
After leaving the America's Best Comics imprint, The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series was published by Top Shelf and Knockabout Comics.
The America's Best Comics imprint of DC Comics published the first two volumes and the graphic novel Black Dossier of The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series.
The first two volumes of The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series were released as two six-issue limited series.
The first two volumes of The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series were released as two six-issue limited series.
A graphic novel, titled Black Dossier, was released from The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series by the America's Best Comics imprint of DC Comics.

After leaving the America's Best Comics imprint, three graphic novellas centered on the character of Nemo were released as a spin-off trilogy from The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series by Top Shelf and Knockabout Comics.
Three graphic novellas, titled Volume III: Century, were released as a spin-off trilogy from The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series by Top Shelf and Knockabout Comics.
The concept behind The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen comic book series was initially a 'Justice League of Victorian England'.
In 1898, Mina Murray is recruited by British Intelligence to protect the interests of the Empire.
Campion Bond asks Mina Murray on behalf of British Intelligence to assemble a league of extraordinary individuals in 1898.
Captain Nemo is asked by the League of Extraordinary Individuals to protect the interests of the Empire.
Allan Quatermain is asked by the League of Extraordinary Individuals to protect the interests of the Empire.
Dr. Jekyll is asked by the League of Extraordinary Individuals to protect the interests of the Empire.
Hawley Griffin the Invisible Man is asked by the League of Extraordinary Individuals to protect the interests of the Empire.
Fu Manchu participates in a gang war with Professor Moriarty, nemesis of Sherlock Holmes.
Professor Moriarty participates in a gang war with Fu Manchu, nemesis of Sherlock Holmes.
Following events that take place after the fall of the Big Brother government from George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty Four, Mina Murray achieves immortality.
Following events that take place after the fall of the Big Brother government from George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty Four, Allan Quatermain achieves immortality.
During an adventure which spans a century, from 1910 to 2009, fellow immortal Orlando is introduced.
During an adventure which spans a century, from 1910 to 2009, Captain Nemo's daughter, Janni Dakkar, is introduced.

node_2: league of extraordinary individuals (after events in 1958)
edge: Following adventures from 1958, Mina Murray remains a part of the League of Extraordinary Individuals.

node_2: league of extraordinary individuals (after events in 1958)
edge: Following adventures from 1958, great-grandson of Captain Nemo, Jack Nemo, remains a part of the League of Extraordinary Individuals.
During adventures from 1958 onwards, a clone of Mr. Hyde is introduced.
In an adventure which spans a century, from 1910 to 2009, a plot by evil magicians to create a Moonchild that might well turn out to be the Antichrist is encountered.
In their final adventure, Mina Murray escapes an Earth dominated by magical entities and various alien invasions to live out her immortal life on a space station.
Alan Moore changed the title of the work from 'The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen' to 'Gentlemen' to better reflect the Victorian era.
Simon Bisley was originally going to be the artist for the series before being replaced by Kevin O'Neill, as mentioned in an interview with Andy Diggle for Comics World website.

The Victorian setting allowed Moore and O'Neill to insert 'in-jokes' and cameos from many works of Victorian fiction, while also making contemporary references and jibes. The works bear numerous steampunk influences.

Most characters in the series, from the dominatrix schoolmistress Rosa Coote to minor characters such as Inspector Dick Donovan, are either established characters from existing works of fiction or ancestors of the same.

In Volume I, individuals depicted in crowd scenes have been said (both by Moore, and in annotations by Jess Nevins) to be visually designed as the ancestors of the cast of the British soap opera EastEnders.

The planet of the imagination is as old as we are, and it has been humanity's constant companion with all its fictional locations, like Mount Olympus and the gods, since we first came down from the trees, basically.

Moore's longstanding, outspoken criticism of DC Comics stemming in large part from what he perceives as mistreatment at their hands over the rights to Watchmen made his position with DC-owned subsidiary Wildstorm Comics tenuous from the start.
Moore agreed to honor his contracts with Lee, who sold his studio to DC after dealing with Moore, but before any of the ABC projects were published.
The entire initial print run was destroyed and reprinted because the publisher felt that this could be perceived as an attack on Marvel Comics, DC's main competition.
After several additional complaints over DC interference, Moore decided to wind up his ABC projects.
Moore intended to only continue with League (the only title he, with O'Neill, actually owned).
Moore requested that someone involved with the film's production company—and DC Comics parent company, Warner Bros.—officially retract the comments and apologize.
Moore took offense at inaccurate comments made by the producer of the film version of his V for Vendetta,
Moore claims that his lack of support from DC regarding a minor lawsuit related to the film adaptation of The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen was instrumental in his departure.

node_1: dc comics parent company, warner bros.
edge: Moore requested that someone involved with the film's production company—and DC Comics parent company, Warner Bros.—officially retract the comments and apologize.

is an extensive appendix included in Volume II of the League series, providing background information for the alternate universe in which the League is set. The Almanac draws from pre-existing literary works and mythology, making some parts difficult to fully appreciate without an esoteric knowledge of literature. It showcases that the plot of the comic is just a small section of a world inhabited by what appears to be the entirety of all fiction ever created.

had an ongoing project with DC/WildStorm called The Black Dossier, which was agreed to be the last League project published by DC/WildStorm due to the lack of apology from their side. Subsequent projects were published jointly by Top Shelf Productions and Knockabout Comics in both the US and UK respectively.

node_2: extensive history of the world of the league and each of its various incarnations
edge: set out an extensive history of the world of the League and each of its various incarnations, threading together hundreds of disparate works of fiction into a cohesive timeline.
The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen won the 1999 UK National Comics Award for Best New Comic (International).
Volume I won the 2000 Bram Stoker Award for Best Illustrated Narrative.
Volume II was nominated for the 2003 award, but lost to The Sandman: Endless Nights. Volume II received the 2003 Eisner Award for Best Finite Series/Limited Series.
Time Magazine listed Volume II as the 9th best comic of 2003.
Time also listed Black Dossier as the second-best comic of 2007.
Neil Gaiman cited The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen as one of the influences for his award-winning short story 'A Study in Emerald'.
Black Thought refers to The Roots as 'gentlemen of an extraordinary league' off the Rising Down album.

Neil Gaiman cited The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen as one of the influences for his award-winning short story 'A Study in Emerald'. This implies that Neil Gaiman's work is related to The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, likely due to its influence on him.

Warren Ellis has cited The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen as an inspiration for his comic Ignition City. This indicates that there is a connection between The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen and Warren Ellis's work, possibly because he was influenced by it.

Critics have referred to The Chimera Brigade as the French response to The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen. This suggests that Serge Lehman's work is related to that of Alan Moore and Kevin O'Neill, likely due to their shared focus on European pulp literature.

In The Chimera Brigade, Serge Lehman mixes real prominent historical figures equally with supervillains and proto-superhumans from European pulp literature of the early twentieth century. This implies a connection between the work and historical figures.

Jess Nevins has produced a series of annotations for each volume of The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen. This indicates that there is a connection between Jess Nevins and the work of Alan Moore and Kevin O'Neill.
